explanation: The chemical in question is likely formaldehyde. Formaldehyde is a known cause of allergic asthma. The diagnosis of asthma is most likely to cause complications with formaldehyde exposure. The other diagnoses are less likely to be exacerbated by formaldehyde exposure.

question: A 67-year-old man with multiple medical problems is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and fever up to $4 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ . The patient has a central line, and he has had multiple episodes of bacteremia in the past two months. The line was not removed the last time. It has been almost a year since the last infection. Sepsis secondary to a central line infection is suspected. He is intubated, sedated, and given intravenous antibiotics. Which of the following best explains why the patient is given antibiotics via the intravenous route?
options: a. The intravenous route is less expensive
b. The oral route is associated with worse gastrointestinal adverse effects
c. Intravenous route achieves higher bioavailability of the drug
d. The patient already has a central line
answer: c. Intravenous route achieves higher bioavailability of the drug
explanation: Critically ill patients may have physiological changes that may result in reduced drug absorption. The intravenous route of administration is associated with $100 \%$ bioavailability. Due to the absence of the absorption process in which the drug is administered directly to the circulation. The oral route will not be the correct answer because it is not the fastest way to reach the maximum effect of the drug with $100 \%$ bioavailability.

question: A 31-year-old man with a history of a polysubstance use disorder, depression, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension is brought to the emergency department confused and agitated, with a sweat-covered shirt stained with vomit. The patient is noted to have a temperature of 40 C. He is admitted to the ICU but rapidly deteriorates and passes away two days later. Which of the following physical examination techniques would have best helped to determine the diagnosis in this patient?
options: a. Swift dorsiflexion of the ankle
b. Auscultation of the lower lobes of the lungs
answer: a. Swift dorsiflexion of the ankle
explanation: Clonus is often evaluated in suspected serotonin syndrome, which can be brought on by many drugs including psychiatric (MAOI, SSRI, SNRI, TCA) or street drugs (cocaine, ecstasy, amphetamines) to name a few. Clonus has been identified as an effective way to predict seizures in patients who have overdosed on tramadol which is an SNRI. Clonus in serotonin syndrome is most often found in the lower extremity. Clonus is an important physical examination maneuver in suspected serotonin syndrome as many of the other similar syndromes do not exhibit clonus. Autonomic instability is common in serotonin syndrome, and hyperthermia is a frequent cause of death. Generally, lungs will be clear, pulsus would not be present, and although there could be orthostatic changes, these would not be as specific and useful a maneuver as assessing clonus.

question: A 30-year-old woman presents with dental caries. Her vital signs are oxygen saturation $9 8 \%$ on room air, respiratory rate 25 breaths/min, heart rate 120 bpm, blood pressure $1 3 0 / 9 0 \mathrm { m m H g }$ , and temperature $9 8 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F }$ $3 6 . 6 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ . On physical examination, there is extensive periodontal disease, especially of the maxillary teeth. She has significant pitting edema in both legs below the knees. On auscultation of the heart, faint S1 and S2 sounds are appreciable. A transthoracic echocardiogram is ordered. Urine is collected for a toxicology screening. What cardiac complication is associated with long-term use of the drug this patient is using?
options: d. Thickening of the left ventricular wall
explanation: Methamphetamine misuse is associated with meth mouth or loss of the maxillary teeth from the snorting of the drug. Chronic heart failure is one of the most common cardiac presentations of the chronic use of methamphetamine. Snorting methamphetamine causes maxillary artery vasoconstriction and loss of blood supply to this dental zone. Methamphetamine also results in negligence of personal hygiene, such as tooth brushing and flossing. Replenishment of energy stores, preferably with sugary foods and beverages, also exacerbates the problem. Methamphetamine users have different symptoms that can be recognized, for example, lack of sleep, acute anxiety, agitation, and psychotic or violent behavior. Methamphetamine users may develop cracked teeth because of extreme clenching of their jaw. Other adverse effects of this drug include long-lasting damage to blood vessels of the heart and brain. Lung, liver, and kidney damage, and hypertension may lead to chronic heart failure, heart attacks, strokes, and death. In the case of sniffing, destruction of soft tissues in the nose, and In the case of smoking, respiratory problems.

question: A 43-year-old man presents to the office with a rash on his foot that began while hiking through the amazon. He states the area is not painful and has a brownish discoloration that has persisted despite trying over the counter topical creams and thoroughly washing the area. What chemical is most likely responsible for the patient's skin findings?
explanation: Millipedes lack the ability to bite, sting or inject venom. Their primary defense mechanisms consist of coiling up and secreting toxins from the sides of their body. Within these secretions a variety of irritating chemicals have been identified, some of which include hydrogen cyanide, hydrochloric acid, hydroquinones, benzoquinones, alkaloids, and phenols, Benzoquinones are more commonly associated with skin discoloration in millipede envenomation. While hydrogen cyanide is caustic and found in the secretions of millipedes, it is not commonly associated with skin discoloration. The phenols found in the secretions of millipedes are more commonly associated with an unpleasant odor. Benzoquinones are more commonly associated with skin discoloration. Hydrochloric acid may cause skin discoloration due to local skin irritation but it's effects are not likely to last as long as benzoquinones.

question: A patient with COPD is currently managed on albuterol, tiotropium, and salmeterol. In what way would you expect his current medications to affect her serum potassium levels?
options: a. Decreased serum $\mathrm { K } +$ due to an increase in intracellular shift.
b. Decreased serum $\mathrm { K } +$ due to increased urinary excretion.
c. Increased serum $\mathrm { K } +$ due to an increase in extracellular shift.
d. Increased serum $\mathrm { K } +$ due to decreased urinary excretion.
answer: a. Decreased serum $\mathrm { K } +$ due to an increase in intracellular shift.
explanation: Beta-2 agonists cause an intracellular shift of $\mathrm { K } +$ into cells through its effect on membrane-bound ATPase. Beta-2 agonists can be used as a temporizing measure for hyperkalemic patients due to their ability to cause a relatively rapid onset of the intracellular shift of $\mathrm { K } +$ . Beta-2 agonists, in addition to hypokalemia, have a relatively common secondary metabolic effect in increasing serum glucose primarily through glycogenolysis. Beta-2 agonists have no association with potassium loss through the kidneys, the mechanism of hypokalemia is correlated with the increase in the shift of serum $\mathrm { K } +$ into the cell.

question: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for disorganized behavior and restlessness. The police found him on the road screaming at cars and damaging property. His blood pressure is $1 5 0 / 9 0 \mathrm { m m } \mathrm { H g }$ , his pulse is 100 bpm, his temperature is $9 9 . 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F }$ $( 3 7 . 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ , and his respiratory rate is 22 breaths/min. He works in a soft-drink company. He has a history of marijuana use. Physical examinations show vertical nystagmus and increased lower limb deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
explanation: Depending on the dose, administration route, and coingestants, PCP can cause a wide spectrum of clinical effects, from a coma to extreme agitation or psychosis. Often, patients cannot give a clear history, so it is imperative to attempt to obtain a history from emergency medical personnel, family, friends, and witnesses. Familiarity with the street names for PCP can be helpful as well. The evaluation should include serum PCP level, fingerstick blood glucose, and complete blood count (leukocytosis, electrolyte panel). BUN and creatinine can be elevated. Creatine kinase has been shown to be elevated in $70 \%$ of cases with PCP toxicity. Acetaminophen and salicylate levels should also be obtained. Electrocardiogram (to evaluate for conduction abnormalities), CT head (to rule out other causes of altered mental status), and cerebral spinal fluid evaluation (to rule out CNS infection) are also required as part of the workup. A urine toxicology screen can be helpful to identify coingestants, but may not be helpful to identify acute PCP intoxication because chronic PCP users can have a positive test weeks after their last use. False positives occur for PCP in patients who use methadone, ibuprofen, venlafaxine, and chlorpromazine. Liver function test is elevated in $5 0 \%$ of cases with PCP toxicity, urinalysis (for elevated myoglobin levels), and imaging studies should be performed when there is a concern for trauma secondary to PCP intoxication. On examination, nystagmus, horizontal, vertical, rotary $( 6 0 \% - 9 0 \% )$ , and miosis may be apparent. Cardiovascular may reveal hypertension $( 6 0 \% )$ and tachycardia $( 3 0 \% )$ . Neurological examination shows mild to severe agitation, confusion, hallucinations, delusions, violent behavior, seizures, muscle rigidity, ataxia, and coma. A thorough examination for evidence of trauma should be completed as injuries secondary to PCP intoxication can occur due to agitation, hallucinations, diminished perception of pain, and delusions of increased physical ability. Marijuana can cause conjunctival injection but not nystagmus. Cocaine may cause some symptoms in this patient but usually causes mydriasis. Amphetamines may cause altered mental status, hyperactivity, agitation, confusion, and gross psychosis.

question: A 9-year-old girl presents with irritability, generalized weakness, and redness of the tip of her nose. After further evaluation, the child is diagnosed with acrodynia secondary to exposure to mercury from a broken thermometer at home. What is the most appropriate recommendation for decontaminating the area where mercury spilled from the thermometer?
options: a. Apply powdered sulfur to the area.
b. Remove the mercury with a wet cloth.
c. Apply hydrogen peroxide to the area.
d. Suction the area with a vacuum.
answer: a. Apply powdered sulfur to the area.
explanation: Environment cleaning is an essential step after a mercury spill in homes and industrial settings. Decontamination prevents further exposure to the toxic effects of mercury, especially the vaporized form. A mercury decontamination kit containing calcium polysulfide or sulfur powder should be used. The sulfur powder converts mercury to waterinsoluble mercuric sulfide. The instructions on the kit should be read thoroughly. One should not use a vacuum cleaner to decontaminate surfaces from mercury. Vacuum cleaning can cause mercury aerosolization. Additionally, using a broom or a mop can break the mercury into smaller droplets, increasing the chance of spread.

question: A 15-year-old female presents with a history of anxiety and depression. After her skin turned pale, a friend brought her to the emergency department in the evening. She takes paroxetine, bupropion, lorazepam, and trazodone. That morning, she confessed to ingesting “many” phenazopyridine from her mother’s medicine cabinet. Her parents are divorced. She lives with her mother, who works at night, and has no relationship with her father. She argued with her boyfriend yesterday. She admits to severe depression. Physical exam shows pale skin, dyspnea, tachycardia, fatigue, and splenomegaly. Her hemoglobin was $8 . 2 { \mathrm { ~ g m } } / { \mathrm { d L } }$ , and her reticulocyte count was $5 . 9 \%$ . Of the erythrocytes, $8 . 2 \%$ contained Heinz bodies. “Bite” cells (degmacytes) are also present. Both direct and indirect Combs’ tests are pending. What is the most likely preliminary diagnosis?
options: a. Drug-induced blood dyscrasia, secondary to an antidepressant
c. Idiopathic Heinz bodies with secondary degmacytes
explanation: The severe adverse events of phenazopyridine are typically limited to overdose cases, long treatment duration, or preexisting renal insufficiency. Two of phenazopyridine's metabolites are implicated in causing the drug's severe adverse events. The metabolite aniline appears to be responsible for methemoglobinemia and hemolytic anemia. The metabolite triaminopyridine seems to be responsible for causing Interstitial nephritis. The presence of Heinz bodies and degmacytes (bite cells) indicates that the erythrocytes experienced severe oxidative stress. The Heinz bodies may result in hemolytic anemia. Mice and rats that received phenazopyridine developed neoplasias. There has been no association between phenazopyridine use in humans and neoplasias.

question: A 26-year-old female was scuba diving off the Northern Coast of Australia. Upon entering the water, she begins to feel a mild stinging sensation in the dorsum of her right hand. Approximately 7 minutes after, before she was able to reach significant depths, she began experiencing severe pain in her trunk and all four limbs. She immediately exited the water with the help of her dive partners. She states, "it just hurts everywhere." She was noted to have small red papules on her right hand, where she initially felt the stinging sensation, and which was one of the only areas of exposed skin. She is speaking in full sentences. She begins to sweat profusely and states she feels her "heart is racing." What is the next best step in management?
options: a. Immediately transport to a hyperbaric oxygen chamber
d. Douse the area with vinegar
answer: d. Douse the area with vinegar
explanation: Irukandji syndrome is a painful condition caused by the venom of several jellyfish (phylum Cnidaria) species. It classically presents with minor pain at the site of the sting, followed by severe systemic symptoms, usually within 30 minutes, but can occur 5 minutes after the initial sting. Symptoms include severe back pain, abdominal pain, diffuse muscle cramping, diaphoresis, anxiety, hypertension, nausea, vomiting, and headache. A sense of “impending doom” has been documented to occur in the scientific literature. Although diving suits made of sting-resistant material such as lycra offer the best in-water protection against stings from Irukandji-causative species, it does not eliminate their occurrence as any area of exposed skin, such as the hands or face can potentially be stung, and it only requires one envenomation to cause the full-blown Irukandji syndrome. Stinger-resistant net enclosures offer little to no protection against these species. Although slightly controversial, the recommended first-aid management by the Australian Resuscitation Council, The Queensland Irukandji Taskforce, and the American Heart Association is to treat the area that was stung with an acetic acid solution, such as or vinegar ( $5 \%$ acetic acid) for approximately 30 seconds to inactivate attached nematocysts. This topic is controversial as in vitro studies demonstrated that acetic acid has the ability to inactive undischarged nematocysts, but also the ability to cause further venom release in already discharged nematocysts. These studies were not performed in Irukandji-causative species, so their generalizability should be interpreted with caution. Hyperbaric oxygen would be indicated if the patient was suffering from decompression sickness, which could also cause diffuse pain, mainly in the joints. However, the fact that the patient developed these symptoms shortly after entering the water, before reaching significant depths, and not during ascent, makes this diagnosis less likely than Irukandji syndrome. Although the patient could develop an allergic reaction from the jellyfish sting, anaphylaxis is rare and has not yet been documented from Irukandji-causative species. Furthermore, the patient is not exhibiting definitive signs of anaphylaxis involving two or more organ systems (cutaneous, pulmonary, hypotension), so epinephrine is not indicated. Although the patient will likely require medications for pain control, this is of lower priority than inactivating or removing attached nematocysts. Additionally, the pain is severe enough to require opioid analgesia rather than simply an NSAID.

question: A 5-year-old female presents to the emergency department after ingesting 2 oral hypoglycemic tablets as witnessed by her older brother 4 hours ago at home. On examination, the patient is confused appearing, tremulous and diaphoretic. Her vitals is notable for tachycardia, at 135 beats/minute, blood pressure of 90/60, respirations 25/minute, SaO2 $9 8 \%$ , and temperature of 37.4 C. The patient is placed on a cardiac monitor, pulse oximetry, and IV access using a 24 gauge catheter is established. No trauma is reported. A STAT point of care finger stick glucose is $4 0 \mathrm { m g / d L }$ shortly after arrival. IV dextrose bolus and infusion is administered for 2 hours and a repeat serum glucose is $5 0 ~ \mathrm { m g / d L }$ one hour after terminating dextrose. At this time, the patient is confused but protecting her airway. Which of the following is the next best step?
options: a. Somatostatin IV followed by dextrose IV
c. Dextrose IV followed by octreotide
explanation: This child is presenting with a severe and potentially life-threatening overdose with an oral hypoglycemic. Sulfonylureas are one of a few xenobiotics that can cause severe life-threatening toxicity with exposure to just one tablet in small children/infants. Sulfonylureas are a class of anti-diabetic medications used orally for the treatment of diabetes mellitus. When ingested alone or in combination with other oral hypoglycemics (e.g. metformin) or insulin, the risk for hypoglycemia increases. Sulfonylureas are especially concerning within the class of oral hypoglycemics due to the propensity to cause hypoglycemia when ingested alone which is less common with other oral hypoglycemics (e.g. metformin) which often become an issue only when combined with other glucose-lowering agents. Further, sulfonylureas are concerning due it's long half-life and duration of toxicity, delayed nature of toxicity, and paradoxical hypoglycemia after administration of sugar products (see below). With a suspected or confirmed sulfonylurea overdose, recognition and treatment of hypoglycemia is critical. Altered mentation, confusion, seizures, diaphoresis, agitation, anxiety, restlessness, lightheadedness, and hallucinations characterize symptoms of hypoglycemia for which one or all may be present. Treatment should first be aimed at raising serum glucose concentrations immediately with either oral glucose or intravenous dextrose if IV has been established. Glucagon can be administered intramuscularly if IV access has not been established or is delayed. Oral glucose is the preferred route to raise serum glucose levels, especially in sulfonylurea overdoses. This is due to the paradoxical nature of persistent hypoglycemia with dextrose administration in the sulfonylurea-toxic patient. Larger boluses of dextrose can cause further hypoglycemia by stimulating more sulfonylurea-induced insulin release in response to larger serum glucose levels. Oral administration of sugar can also cause this paradoxical effect but less frequently as compared to intravenous dextrose. Octreotide is used in cases of sulfonylurea-induced hypoglycemia based on its mechanism of action on islet pancreatic beta cells. Octreotide binds to the sulfonylurea receptor on the ATP-dependent potassium efflux channels. The result of octreotide binding to its receptor results in the closing and therefore termination of potassium ions effluxed to the extracellular space. This results in downstream deactivation of the secondary messenger cAMP and subsequently retarding the release of insulin granules into the bloodstream. Somatostatin can be used in cases of Sulfonylurea induced hypoglycemia; however, octreotide is more specific for its receptor. Glucagon can be used in the initial management of severe hypoglycemia where IV access has not been established for any reason. IV access should eventually be used so that IV dextrose can be used in cases where oral glucose is contraindicated (e.g. unable to protect the airway, aspiration risk). Finally, octreotide IV should be administered in cases of either delayed, rebound, or persistent hypoglycemia.

question: A 48-year-old woman presents for abdominal pain. The abdominal pain has gradually worsened over the past month. She also reports recent joint pains, fatigue, and headache. On further history, the patient states she started a new job two months ago where she works in a factory that produces batteries. Laboratory evaluation reveals that the patient has a blood lead level of 98 mcg/dL. Chelation with calcium EDTA is planned. Which of the following possible factors is most likely to affect treatment in this patient?
explanation: Calcium EDTA is commonly administered to patients with blood lead levels over 70 mcg/dL. This patient meets the criteria with levels at 98 mcg/dL. Prior to the administration of calcium EDTA, active or chronic kidney disease must be excluded from the patient's history. Additionally, patients with hepatitis are contraindicated from taking calcium EDTA. Calcium EDTA is mainly cleared from the body by the kidneys. Therefore, patients with chronic kidney disease can develop worsening renal function and elevated drug levels. While limited, there have been reports of EDTA being beneficial to reduce coronary artery disease. With heavy metals' negative effects on the cardiovascular system, EDTA has been proposed as a useful agent against the development of atherosclerosis.

question: A middle-aged male presents from home after becoming unresponsive after a reported ingestion. The patient's friend reports that they were making "Molotov cocktails." The patient was seen drinking from one of the unmarked bottles that contained the reported mixture. Paramedics reported that the patient was in ventricular tachycardia on their arrival. The patient was cardioverted and brought to the hospital. On arrival, the patient is unresponsive, hypotensive, and tachycardic to 160 bpm. The patient is found to be in ventricular tachycardia. The patient receives several electrical cardioversions but remains in ventricular tachycardia. What treatment may be helpful in the management of this patient?
explanation: This patient presents after ingestion of a mixture termed a "Molotov cocktail." A Molotov cocktail is similar to napalm in that a component is usually a hydrocarbon fuel, such as kerosene. Hydrocarbons can cause ventricular dysrhythmias as a result of exposure, either by inhalation or ingestion. The dysrhythmia results from increased sensitivity of the myocardium due to the hydrocarbon exposure and a subsequent sympathetic surge. Beta-adrenergic antagonists will mitigate the effect of the sympathetic system on the myocardium and will increase the chances of successful cardioversion. Epinephrine and calcium channel blockers are likely to worsen the patient's dysrhythmia and could lead to cardiac arrest. Electrical cardioversion is unlikely to work as this patient has already had multiple unsuccessful attempts.

question: A 44-year-old female with a history of chronic migraine headaches and epilepsy controlled with topiramate presents to the emergency department with somnolence, agitation, mydriasis, and vertigo. The patient reports a suicide attempt by consuming a bottle of pills prescribed to her. What is the most appropriate antidote for this patient's overdose?
options: d. No antidote exists; supportive treatment is advised
answer: d. No antidote exists; supportive treatment is advised
explanation: In 7 cases of topiramate toxicity observed by Polish Poison Control Centers, the most common symptom for TPM toxicity is somnolence $( 6 6 . 7 \% )$ , along with agitation, mydriasis, and vertigo $( 3 3 . 4 \% )$ . There have been no fatalities or long-term consequences observed. There is no antidote for topiramate overdose; treatment is supportive only. Cyproheptadine is used for SSRI overdose. Acetylcysteine is used for acetaminophen overdose. Corticosteroids are not used for this overdose.

question: A 33-year-old man presents by EMS after being found drowsy and confused in his bedroom. His wife found an empty bottle of lorazepam lying beside his bed. His history is significant for generalized anxiety disorder. Vital signs are blood pressure $1 1 0 / 7 0 \mathrm { m m H g }$ , heart rate 82 bpm, and respiratory rate 11 breaths/min. On physical examination, he has slurred speech and is disoriented to time, place, or person. The patient’s gait is unsteady, and during the examination, he suddenly loses consciousness. Suspecting a drug overdose, the patient is immediately resuscitated, and an antidote was infused. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this antidote?
options: a. Inhibits activation of GABA-B ligand-gated chloride ion channel
b. Inhibits activation of GABA-A voltage-gated sodium ion channel
c. Inhibits activation of GABA-A ligand-gated chloride ion channel
d. Inhibits activation of GABA-B voltage-gated calcium ion channel
answer: c. Inhibits activation of GABA-A ligand-gated chloride ion channel
explanation: This scenario describes a case of benzodiazepine toxicity. Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is an amino acid that serves as an important inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain and spinal cord. GABA binds to two major postsynaptic receptors, the GABA-A and GABA-B receptors. The GABA-A receptor is an ionotropic ligand-gated chloride ion channel that increases chloride ion conductance in the presence of GABA, thereby hyperpolarizing the postsynaptic cell and inhibiting the transmission of an action potential. Benzodiazepines are a class of drugs that act upon benzodiazepine receptors (BZ-R) in the central nervous system (CNS). The receptor is a protein comprised of five transmembrane subunits that form a chloride channel in the center, i.e., the GABA-A receptor. Activation of the BZ-R causes a conformational change to a central pore, which allows the entrance of chloride ions into the neuron. The influx of the chloride anion hyperpolarizes the neuron, resulting in the decreased firing of action potentials of that neuron. Flumazenil is a GABA-A receptor antagonist, acting to reverse the sedative effects of benzodiazepines. Flumazenil functions through competitive inhibition of the alpha-gamma subunit of the GABA-A receptor. Administration of flumazenil should be carried out judiciously, as it may precipitate withdrawal seizures. It is useful in reversing coma due to benzodiazepine overdose.

question: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a bilateral posterior headache. In triage, the patient's vitals are blood pressure of 225/105 mmHg, heart rate of 80 beats/min, respiratory rate of 15 breaths/min, and $100 \%$ oxygen saturation on room air. He is evaluated and diagnosed with a hypertensive emergency. Treatment with nitroglycerin is initiated. The clinician returns later, and the patient is found to be cyanotic. He complains of feeling light-headed and his heart racing. The clinician realizes the nitroglycerin drip is set at twice the expected dose. A blood gas analysis shows a PO2 of ${ 9 0 } \mathrm { m m H g }$ and PCO2 of 36 mmHg. In addition to stopping the nitroglycerin, which of the following is the most appropriate for managing this patient?
options: c. Administration of an ACE inhibitor to reduce blood pressure
d. Administration of a beta-blocker to reduce heart rate
explanation: Nitroglycerin can cause cyanosis by producing methemoglobinemia and can be fatal. Methemoglobin levels can be measured. The treatment is methylene blue administration. Nitroglycerin use is contraindicated in patients with increased intracranial pressure, severe anemia, methemoglobinemia, and circulatory collapse. Nitroglycerin should not be used within 24 hours of PDE5 inhibitor use.

question: A 54-year-old man with a past medical history of alcoholic liver disease presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, generalized myalgia, headache, and weakness. He works at a factory, smelting and refining lead. Laboratory findings reveal whole blood lead concentration $1 0 2 \mathrm { m c g / d L }$ , AST 85 IU/L, ALT 22 IU/L, BUN 25 $\mathrm { m g / d L }$ , creatinine $1 . 6 \ : \mathrm { m g / d L }$ . What is the most likely primary concern, if any, with starting combination chelation therapy in this patient?
options: a. Elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels
b. There are no concerns with starting combination chelation therapy
c. History of alcoholic liver disease and elevated liver enzymes

d. The whole blood lead concentration is below that which is recommended   
for chelation therapy
answer: c. History of alcoholic liver disease and elevated liver enzymes
explanation: Dimercaprol is contraindicated in hepatic insufficiency. In animal studies by Cameron et al, rabbits and mice with hepatic damage treated with dimercaprol experienced toxic symptoms and some died. These results occurred with doses well below the lethal dose in healthy animals. Dimercaprol is not contraindicated with renal impairment. No adjustments are needed when starting therapy, but if acute kidney injury develops during treatment, discontinuation of dimercaprol is recommended. Dimercaprol is given before calcium disodium edetate, another chelating agent, to prevent redistribution of lead to the brain. Symptomatic lead poisoning, lead encephalopathy, and a whole blood lead concentration $= 1 0 0 \mathrm { m c g / d L }$ in adults and $= 7 0 \mathrm { m c g / d L }$ in children are indications for treatment with dimercaprol.

question: A 65-year-old male currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) needs to be initiated therapy with intravenous sodium phenytoin. What dose needs to be given if the desired steady-state concentration is $2 0 \mathrm { m g / L }$ and the volume of distribution is 60 L?
explanation: A loading dose is calculated for initiation therapy to achieve a desired plasma drug concentration that can be maintained by the maintenance dose. It is measured by multiplying the desired steady-state concentration by the volume of distribution. Once that is calculated, you divide the answer by the bioavailability. The bioavailability of a drug delivered intravenously is 1.0, or $100 \%$ , whereas if the drug is taken by the oral route, the bioavailability will be reduced. Loading doses are needed to reach a therapeutic drug state quickly or to provide a clinical response immediately. Calculating the loading dose for certain drugs is important because if a dose above the therapeutic window is administered, this could lead to drug toxicities. Alternatively, if a dose below the therapeutic window is administered, the patient will not get a clinical response.

question: A 28-year-old male is applying for a new job. He has a history of substance use disorders, including cocaine, ecstasy, marijuana, and heavy alcohol use. He has abstained from using all of these substances for over two weeks. He still tests positive for a substance on the urine drug screen despite abstinence. What is the likely underlying mechanism for this prolonged detection period?
options: a. Continued use despite stating abstinence
b. Increased elimination in the urine
explanation: The length of time a urine drug screen for marijuana remains positive after use depends on the frequency of smoking and the threshold of detection for the screen. With increased use, marijuana concentrates in fatty tissue. With cessation, this is subsequently eliminated slowly. One-time use of marijuana will lead to a positive urine test for 5 to 8 days. Using marijuana 2 to 4 times a week will lead to a positive urine test for 23 to 35 days. Daily usage of marijuana may lead to a positive urine test for 49 to 63 days. Although secondary exposure could lead to a positive result, the required exposure would have to be significant and often is unlikely to occur in most scenarios.

question: A 35-year-old man is scuba diving when he picks up a cone-shaped shell and feels immediate severe pain. He swims back to the boat and informs the captain. The patient’s hand is beginning to swell. The captain decides to head to shore, and an ambulance is called for transport to the nearest hospital. What management can be provided while the patient is transported to the hospital?
options: a. The hospital should be warned so that they can prepare antivenin on arrival.
b. A 3-centimeter incision should be made at the site of envenomation to help drain out the toxin.
c. The affected limb should be immobilized and a pressure dressing placed. 4. The patient should be placed on high-flow oxygen.
answer: c. The affected limb should be immobilized and a pressure dressing placed. 4. The patient should be placed on high-flow oxygen.
explanation: The priority after cone snail envenomation is to seek emergent hospitalbased therapy to stabilize the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation. While in transport, some additional methods can be utilized to prevent venom spread. Pressure immobilization involves bandaging the limb starting at the distal end (fingers or toes) and moving toward the axial joints. This technique is suggested to prevent further injury following envenomation. The wrapping should be tight but not to the point that circulation is affected. There should be a frequent examinations to ensure that the most distal parts (i.e., fingers, toes) remain pink. Recommendations are that the bandages be removed for 90 seconds and reapplied every 10 minutes, but this should in no way impact the speed of transport to a hospital. There is no antivenin for cone snail envenomations. Incising the wound does not prevent the spread of toxins. Oxygen is the immediate treatment for suspected decompression illness.

question: A 45-year-old male with a past medical history of alcohol use disorder for the past several years presents for evaluation of pain in his feet. He describes the pain as sharp and constant. It extends from his toes to his ankles bilaterally. He denies any trauma. On examination, he has decreased vibratory sensation at the distal feet bilaterally and decreased 2- point discrimination. His vital signs are within normal limits. What is the most likely result of erythrocyte transketolase activity in this patient?
options:
d. There is no correlation between his disease and erythrocyte transketolase   
activity
explanation: Peripheral neuropathy is a common complication of prolonged alcohol use disorder. Nutritional deficiencies, particularly thiamine deficiency, can sometimes complicate alcohol-associated peripheral neuropathy. Thiamine deficiency has been shown to play a contributory (but not exclusive) role in the pathogenesis of alcoholic peripheral neuropathy. Alcoholic peripheral neuropathy is primarily an axonal neuropathy. When thiamine deficiency is present, this is complicated by demyelination. Erythrocyte transketolase activity is a marker of thiamine deficiency and is likely to be reduced in patients with alcoholic peripheral neuropathy that is complicated by vitamin deficiency.

question: A 47-year-old woman presents accompanied by police with erratic and combative behavior and painless, involuntary body movements. Physical examination shows diaphoresis and hyperactive bowel sounds. Her belongings are collected and include a pipe. Which of the following is most likely to be detected on this patient's urine toxicology screen?
explanation: This patient presents with a sympathomimetic toxidrome secondary to acute cocaine toxicity. The commonly used urine screening assays for cocaine work through the detection of the primary metabolite of cocaine, benzoylecgonine, rather than the parent compound. This metabolite is detectable in the urine within 4 hours of use and can remain detectable for up to 1 week in heavy or prolonged use. Thus, positive detection does not necessarily indicate acute intoxication. These assays are characterized by a high sensitivity and specificity for benzoylecgonine. Accumulation of this compound may also be detected in a patient's hair sample. Acute cocaine intoxication results in a sympathomimetic toxidrome which may be distinguished from anticholinergic toxicity by the presence of diaphoresis and increased bowel sounds versus anhidrosis and depressed bowel sounds. Cocaine toxicity may result in seizures and wide-complex tachycardias, the latter of which is treated with sodium bicarbonate. Treatment also centers on benzodiazepines and strict avoidance of betablockers which may lead to an unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation. Unlike the hydrochloride form, the alkaloid form of cocaine is the heatstable type that is smoked as "crack."

question: A 26-year-old man is brought with fever, headache, vomiting, diarrhea, and myalgia for three days. He is a victim of a bioterrorist attack where a ‘flavivirus’ was used as the bioweapon. The patient’s vital signs show a heart rate of $1 1 0 / \mathrm { m i n }$ , blood pressure of 110/80 mmHg, respiratory rate of $2 2 / \mathrm { { m i n } }$ , and temperature of 102 F (38.8 C). On examination, he is confused with signs of overt psychosis and has dystonia and choreo-athetoid movements. MRI brain shows bilateral thalamic lesions. A CSF study shows significant opening pressure elevation, increased protein, and normal glucose. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Japanese encephalitis is caused by a flavivirus and is transmitted by Culex mosquitos. Japanese encephalitis and West Nile virus are potentially transmissible by aerosolization, which makes them a potential bioweapon. Nipah virus belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family. Q fever is caused by Coxiella burnetii, which is a rickettsial organism. San Joaquin Valley fever is the other name for coccidioides infection.

question: A 4-year-old girl presents with tachycardia, lethargy, and seizures. She has no significant history and takes no medications. She lives at home with her mother, who takes no medications, and her grandmother, who takes "something for depression." No one witnessed any ingestion. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
options:
a. Continue cardiac monitoring and administer bicarbonate to alkalize the   
serum to 7.5 to 7.55 to prevent dysrhythmias.
b. Induce vomiting to rid the body of any potential toxins left in the stomach.
answer:
a. Continue cardiac monitoring and administer bicarbonate to alkalize the   
serum to 7.5 to 7.55 to prevent dysrhythmias.
explanation: This patient's history and symptoms are suspicious for tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) ingestion. TCA ingestions often have serious central nervous system and cardiac effects in children. Hypotension can be treated with intravenous fluid boluses initially. If there is no improvement, then norepinephrine is considered since tricyclics block the uptake of norepinephrine, which can lead to worsening hypotension. An ECG is obtained, and a wide QRS or ventricular irritability may be present. These cardiotoxic effects can be treated with sodium bicarbonate and hypertonic saline. A bicarbonate drip may be required. If a bicarbonate infusion is being administered, then it must have a dedicated IV and cannot be mixed with other medications. Inducing vomiting is contraindicated because of aspiration. A Foley may need to be placed to prevent urinary retention and monitor output. Benzodiazepines may be needed for seizures. Monitor temperature and electrolytes frequently. A normal heart rate is 80 to 140 bpm, and the normal respiratory rate is 22 to 34 breaths/min. Systolic blood pressure should be above 78 mmHg. Systolic blood pressure ${ \ge } 7 0 + ( 2 \mathrm { ~ x ~ }$ age in years) is the lowest acceptable reading. Norepinephrine is not effective. IV N-acetylcysteine is used for acetaminophen ingestions.

question: A 1-month-old boy presents with lethargy and abdominal distention. He was delivered prematurely at 34 weeks gestation by a cesarian section. He is exclusively breastfed since birth. His mother's history is significant for taking chloramphenicol during the length of pregnancy. Physical examination demonstrates hypotension, tachycardia, ash-colored skin, and abdominal distention. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
explanation: The presentation of a neonate with abdominal distention, cyanosis, and ashen-gray skin discoloration is classic for gray-baby syndrome secondary to either fetal or maternal chloramphenicol use. Gray-baby syndrome occurs because of decreased renal clearance and immature hepatic detoxification by uridine 5'-diphosphateglucuronosyltransferase. Gray-baby syndrome can result in permanent neurologic deficits or death secondary to chloramphenicol's displacement of unconjugated bilirubin from albumin, leading to kernicterus. Management of chloramphenicol toxicity centers primarily around supportive care. The general approach to the ashen-gray hemodynamically unstable neonate starts with aggressive resuscitation and an early call to the pediatric intensive care unit or extracorporeal life support team, as some of these patients may be ideal candidates. These patients should be hemodynamically stabilized, appropriately oxygenated and ventilated, and intubated early. Checking a core temperature is critical, as hypothermia is common in the gray neonate. Aggressive rewarming should be considered. Point-of-care glucose should also be checked, and hypoglycemia should be reversed if present.

question: A 50-year-old woman presents with daily generalized headaches for a month. She reports the headaches are worst at night and in the morning before work. She recently separated from her husband of 25 years and moved into an older house. Her history is significant for depression and she was started on an SSRI after her pet cat died in the basement. Her neurologist prescribed sumatriptan for the headaches. One week later, the patient is brought to the emergency department by paramedics, unresponsive and flushed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Carbon monoxide from an old furnace could cause this scenario. The cat died of chronic exposure, while the patient had headaches at home. Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin, causing progressive cerebral anoxia. Other symptoms associated with carbon monoxide are dizziness and fl like symptoms, while patients with poisoning have flushing and pink skin.

question: A 17-year-old girl presents with anxiety, restlessness, facial flushing, and muscle twitching. She is accompanied by a friend who reports that the patient has been irritable with rapid speech. She admits to drinking "energy" drinks and coffee. Vital signs are heart rate 110 bpm and blood pressure $1 5 2 / 8 8 \mathrm { m m H g }$ . The major electrolyte disturbance associated with this intoxication is sometimes associated with which electrocardiographic abnormality?
options: a. ST-segment elevation in lateral leads
b. Focal ST-segment depressions in precordial leads
c. An upright "T" wave followed by a "u" wave
d. T-wave inversions in inferior leads
answer: c. An upright "T" wave followed by a "u" wave
explanation: This patient presents with anxiety, restlessness, facial flushing, and muscle twitching in addition to tachycardia and hypertension. Of the options provided, her symptoms are most consistent with a diagnosis of caffeine toxicity due to excess consumption of energy drinks. Caffeine is commonly associated with hypokalemia, which sometimes can manifest as a "u" wave on the electrocardiogram. Lethal doses of caffeine have been reported at blood concentrations of 80 to $1 0 0 \mathrm { \ m c g / m L }$ , which can be reached with ingestion of approximately $1 0 { \mathrm { ~ g ~ } }$ or more. These cases are often associated with decreased potassium levels. Physical exam findings characteristic of caffeine toxicity include fever, tachycardia or bradycardia, and hypertension early on, followed by hypotension. Pupils may demonstrate mydriasis. A neurologic exam may demonstrate altered mentation, agitation, delusional thought, hallucinations, or seizures.

question: A 25-year-old man presents 20 minutes after ingesting 10 g of cadmium in a suicide attempt. His kidney function is normal. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?
explanation: Cadmium is a heavy metal that causes direct harm to humans in several forms. Cadmium toxicity usually occurs after occupational, environmental, or hobby work exposure. DMPS (2,3 mercapto-1-propane sulfonate) or succimer [DMSA (2,3 dimercaptosuccinic acid)] is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient. Hemodialysis and hemoperfusion are not useful in the treatment of cadmium ingestion. In patients with severe renal damage, hemodialysis is useful in restoring kidney function.

question: A 55-year-old hospital environmental services personnel presents to the occupational health clinic complaining of a rash on his arms and legs with itching and burning sensations. The patient reports exposure to various cleaning agents at work. He denies other symptoms or known medical history. He did report trying multiple over-the-counter emollients and topical anti-allergy medications without relief. Diagnostic studies were unremarkable. Which intervention most effectively prevents dermatitis due to chronic exposure to cleaning solutions containing quaternary ammonium compounds?
options: a. Providing gloves made of natural rubber latex
b. Implementing engineering controls such as ventilation systems

c. Using cleaning solutions with lower concentrations of quaternary   
ammonium compounds
d. Providing annual medical monitoring and screening
answer:
c. Using cleaning solutions with lower concentrations of quaternary   
ammonium compounds
explanation: Dermatitis is a common adverse health effect associated with chronic exposure to cleaning solutions containing quaternary ammonium compounds, particularly among hospital environmental services. The best approach to preventing dermatitis due to quaternary ammonium compounds exposure is through a combination of measures, including administrative, engineering, and personal protective equipment (PPE) controls. Using cleaning solutions with lower concentrations of quaternary ammonium compounds is the most effective intervention to reduce exposure to the compounds and prevent dermatitis. This measure can also help limit the development of microbial resistance to QACcontaining solutions. All other options can provide some protection against acute exposure to cleaning solutions. However, they may not be effective in preventing dermatitis if the skin is exposed to the compounds for extended periods.

question: A public health department is surveying a neighborhood for possibly toxic radon levels. They designate an area as Zone 1 for the highest potential of radon toxicity. For a basement-type home in the neighborhood, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation to reduce radon levels effectively?
options: b. Installing suction pipes into the floor and venting them to the outdoors.
c. Adding a plastic sheet to the earth floor and venting it to the outdoors.
d. Sealing cracks around the home.
answer: b. Installing suction pipes into the floor and venting them to the outdoors.
explanation: For basement and slab-on-grade houses, radon levels are reduced by 1 of the 4 types of soil suction: sub-slab suction, drain tile suction, sump hole suction, or block wall suction. Active sub-slab suction is the most effective way to reduce radon levels in basement-type houses. Crawlspace houses usually utilize submembrane suction to reduce radon levels. This involves covering the earth floor with a plastic sheet and venting it outside. Sealing, natural ventilation, heat recovery ventilation, and house/room pressurization are other methods that can be used in all types of homes but cannot be used on their own effectively.

question: Which of the following is a concern with the IV formulation of the medication used to treat an elevated INR caused by excess warfarin?
explanation: When patients present with an elevated INR following treatment with oral anticoagulants such as warfarin, the best antidote is vitamin K. Vitamin K can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly in a 10 mg dose. Parenteral administration will correct the INR more quickly but has a much greater risk of an anaphylactoid reaction. Parenteral administration of vitamin K1 (phytonadione) is traditionally preferred as initial therapy by many authors, but success can also be achieved with early oral therapy, especially when the coagulopathy is not severe.

question: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatric emergency department unresponsive to tactile stimulation. He was found with depressed consciousness next to an open package of buprenorphine-naloxone. He was born full-term and he has no known medical conditions. He takes no medications and has no known drug or food allergies. His vital signs show blood pressure of $8 0 / 5 0 \ \mathrm { m m H g }$ , pulse of $9 0 / \mathrm { m i n }$ , temperature of 35.9 C, oxygen saturation of $9 6 \%$ on room air, and respiratory rate of $1 0 / \mathrm { m i n }$ . Physical examination is significant for slow shallow breathing, miosis, hyporeflexia, and absence of bowel sounds. His blood glucose level is 90 mg/dl and a chest radiograph reveals clear lungs without effusion or infiltrate. What receptor agonism is helping to prevent mortality in this patient?
explanation: This patient is experiencing adverse effects from mu receptor activation including depressed consciousness, hypotension, hypothermia, bradypnea, hypoxia, miosis, hyporeflexia, and decreased bowel peristalsis. This constellation of signs and symptoms is commonly referred to as opioid toxicity. The primary risk of mortality associated with opioid toxicity is respiratory depression from mu receptor activation. This young child is experiencing signs of respiratory depression. Activation of the nociception protein receptor stimulates breathing. This is one mechanism that contributes to the ceiling effect regarding the degree of respiratory depression that buprenorphine can cause. Kappa receptors activation may reduce pruritus and delta receptor activation may be beneficial for the treatment of chronic pain and depression. Kappa and delta receptor activation have no significant effect on respiratory drive. Mu receptor activation will depress respiratory drive.

question: A 21-year-old man presents with irritability, aggressive behavior, seeing aliens in the room, and breathlessness. His friend says he took "rocket fuel" over the past 2 weeks. Vital signs are blood pressure $1 7 0 / 9 0 \mathrm { m m H g } .$ , heart rate 100 bpm, and oxygen saturation $9 3 \%$ on room air. Physical examination shows miosis and nystagmus. Which of the following is the best initial therapy?
explanation: Phencyclidine (PCP) is a dissociative anesthetic that is a commonly used recreational drug. PCP is a crystalline powder that can be ingested orally, injected intravenously, inhaled, or smoked. PCP is available as a powder, crystal, liquid, and tablet. It produces both stimulation and depression of the CNS. PCP is a non-competitive antagonist to the NMDA receptor, which causes analgesia, anesthesia, cognitive defects, and psychosis. PCP blocks dopamine and norepinephrine uptake, leading to sympathomimetic effects such as hypertension, tachycardia, bronchodilation, and agitation. Sedation with medication and physical restraints may be required to control agitation, violent behavior, and psychosis due to PCP intoxication. Placing the patient in a calm environment such as a quiet room with the lights dimmed may help. Benzodiazepines are the preferred medication for chemical sedation in patients with PCP toxicity. Lorazepam 2 to $4 \ : \mathrm { m g }$ intravenous (IV) or intramuscular (IM) or diazepam 5 to 10 mg IV or IM are recommended. Repeated doses every 10 minutes may be required for adequate sedation. Benzodiazepines are also the first-line treatment for PCP-induced hypertension and seizures. Hyperthermia from PCP toxicity is due to psychomotor agitation and can be successfully treated with benzodiazepines as well. Most patients survive PCP intoxication with supportive care. Airway, breathing, circulation, and hemodynamic monitoring are essential to patients' care with PCP toxicity. Intubation with ventilatory support may be required for airway protection.

question: A 68-year-old man presents with a severely painful red eye. His history is significant for multiple myeloma. He had an allogeneic stem cell transplant 2 months ago, and he is currently on bortezomib and prednisone as maintenance therapy. His specialist recently increased his prednisone dose and arranged for IV zoledronic acid infusion, which he had 4 days ago. Vital signs are temperature $3 7 . 2 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ $( 9 8 . 9 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )$ , respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, SpO2 $9 6 \%$ on room air, heart rate 102 bpm, and blood pressure 155/67 mm Hg. A physical examination of the face shows a red right eye with no swelling or erythema in or around the orbital cavity. The rest of his physical examination findings are unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The 2 most common bisphosphonates which cause uveitis are pamidronate and zoledronic acid. This condition is diagnosed by a slitlamp examination. Bisphosphonates can cause ocular complications, even in the recommended doses. Ocular complications caused by bisphosphonates are serious complications and require ophthalmologist specialist input. Bisphosphonates are not known to cause keratitis; instead, it causes conjunctivitis. Bisphosphonates do not cause optic neuritis. They can also cause scleritis, but not episcleritis. Both conditions are not that painful.

question: Which vitamin deficiency may occur in a patient on isoniazid?
explanation: Isoniazid is a first-line treatment for tuberculosis. Peripheral neuropathy is due to pyridoxine (vitamin B6) depletion. Isoniazid is a prodrug that needs to be activated by a bacterial catalaseperoxidase enzyme called KAT. Adverse effects include abnormal liver tests, high anion gap metabolic acidosis, peripheral neuropathy, and disulfiram-like effect. Isoniazid reaches high concentrations in the cerebrospinal fluid and within the tuberculosis granuloma. It must be continued for at least six to nine months.

question: A 30-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for an intermittent fever that is not responding to acetaminophen. The patient reports that he started feeling very sick three days ago after he injected "green eggs" that a friend gave him because he was not getting his "normal high" anymore with fentanyl and because he wanted to feel relaxed from all the stress caused by his family. On review of the systems, the patient complains of excruciating pain in the left thigh and chest pain. The patient has a medical history of hepatitis C. His father died from endocarditis at the age of 37. He is single and unemployed. VS: BP: 147/82, HR: 112, T: 103.2 F. On physical examination, the patient appears cachectic, with multiple track marks on his arms and legs. CBC: red blood cells: 4.1 million/mm3, red blood cell distribution width: $1 1 . 5 \%$ , white blood cells: 17 thousand/mm3, platelets: 261 thousand/mm3, hemoglobin: 7.2 grams per deciliter, and hematocrit: $30 \%$ . EKG result is pending. What would be the most realistic goal to mitigate further complications?
options: a. "Green eggs" are slightly soluble in water and sparingly soluble in alcohol. Infection linked to the capsule intravenously injected is likely. Thus, refer the patient to syringe service programs and start buprenorphine.

b. "Green eggs" are slightly non-soluble in water and sparingly non-soluble in alcohol, and the hazards and consequences connected with intravenous injection are likely. Thus, refer the patient to syringe service programs and start buprenorphine.

c. "Green eggs" are slightly soluble in water and sparingly soluble in alcohol, and the hazards and consequences connected with intravenous injection are likely. Thus, refer the patient to syringe service programs and start   
methadone.

d. "Green eggs" are slightly non-soluble in water and sparingly non-soluble in alcohol, and the hazards and consequences connected with intravenous injection are likely. Thus, refer the patient to syringe service programs and start methadone.
answer: a. "Green eggs" are slightly soluble in water and sparingly soluble in alcohol. Infection linked to the capsule intravenously injected is likely. Thus, refer the patient to syringe service programs and start buprenorphine.
explanation: Temazepam is often known as "green eggs" on the street. Intravenously administered green egg capsules have been linked to arterial thrombosis, compartment syndrome, gangrene, and rhabdomyolysis. The most pragmatic objective is to advocate for the implementation of syringe service programs to mitigate additional harm, as it is probable that the patient has engaged in needle sharing or utilized unsterilized needles, leading to the present infection and hepatitis C. Risk reduction is feasible if hazards are defined, and measures are taken to reduce them. Starting buprenorphine is appropriate as this can mitigate further exposure to illicit opioid use and decrease the risk of medical complications. Referring the patient to syringe service programs and starting buprenorphine is appropriate, as this can mitigate exposure to illicit opioid use and reduce medical complications. However, "green eggs" are soluble in water and alcohol, not non-soluble. Refer the patient to syringe service programs to avoid further damage. Green eggs" are slightly soluble in water and sparingly soluble in alcohol. It is not safe to start methadone if the patient is complaining of chest pain. Methadone may cause QT prolongation and torsades de pointes. Refer the patient to syringe service programs to avoid further damage. Note that “green eggs" are soluble in water and alcohol, not non-soluble. It is not safe to start methadone if the patient is complaining of chest pain. Methadone may cause QT prolongation and torsades de pointes.

question: A 24-year-old woman presents by ambulance approximately 15 minutes following a snake bite to her left forearm. She and her friends were hiking in the woods when she encountered a small snake. She picked the snake up by the tail, during which time it turned its head and upper body towards her forearm and bit her. The patient says the snake had vertical-slit pupils and made a rattling sound. Vital signs are heart rate 106 bpm, blood pressure $1 1 0 / 7 0 \mathrm { m m H g }$ , respiratory rate 22 breaths/min, oxygen saturation $9 7 \%$ on room air, and temperature 98.6 F (37 C). Physical examination shows 2 puncture marks to the dorsal side of her mid-forearm with surrounding edema and erythema approximately 3 cm in diameter. There is no perioral or lip swelling or signs of external bleeding. Laboratory testing reveals a platelet count of $^ { 1 5 5 , 0 0 0 / \mu \mathrm { L } }$ , PT 12 sec, PTT 30 sec, and fibrinogen $4 5 \mathrm { m g / d L }$ (ref. range: $2 0 0 { - } 4 0 0 \ \mathrm { m g / d L } \$ ). What is the best next step in management?
options: a. Tourniquet the left upper extremity to halt the spread of the venom.
b. Administer 6 vials of anti-venom (Crotalidae polyvalent immune Fab).

c. Observe for 8 hours, and discharge home if no clinical signs of   
deterioration.
answer: b. Administer 6 vials of anti-venom (Crotalidae polyvalent immune Fab).
explanation: Aside from imported snake species, North American venomous snakebites involve the pit vipers (Crotalinae subfamily of Viperidae) or coral snakes (Elapidae family). The description of this North American snake as having vertically oriented pupils and making a rattling sound is consistent with a rattlesnake, which is a pit viper family, rather than a coral snake. Although this patient exhibits clinically minimal signs of envenomation, her decreased fibrinogen level is a sign of envenomation rather than a dry bite. Pit viper bites are dry approximately $2 5 \%$ of the time. Laboratory abnormalities, including decreased fibrinogen, are indications for antivenom administration. Other indications include progressive swelling, elevated PT/PTT, decreased platelets, or systemic symptoms. Tourniquets are never recommended for pit viper envenomation as their use can increase local tissue toxicity. Although this patient's fibrinogen is low, a transfusion of cryoprecipitate or any blood products is not indicated in this hemodynamically stable patient without signs of bleeding. Antivenom should be given as the first-line treatment.

question: A 41-year-old female with a history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital for cellulitis on her left foot. She has been receiving intravenous vancomycin for the past two days without improvement in her symptoms. Vancomycin trough levels are ordered and returned as $4 \mathrm { m c g / m L }$ . If the experimental volume of distribution of vancomycin is approximately $0 . 4 0 \mathrm { L } / \mathrm { k g } .$ , and the patient weighs $8 0 \mathrm { k g } .$ , how much vancomycin is currently in the patient's system?
explanation: Vancomycin trough levels were ordered because of the patient's poor response to antibiotics. The results that returned reflected an abnormally low vancomycin trough level. This can result in ineffective antibiotic action and the development of antibiotic resistance. To determine the amount of vancomycin currently in her system, it is necessary to have the trough level as well as the volume of distribution. The volume of distribution is given as $0 . 4 \mathrm { L } / \mathrm { k g }$ . When corrected for her weight, that returns as a volume of distribution of 32 liters. The trough level reflects the current vancomycin concentration, so $4 \mathrm { m c g / m L }$ is multiplied by the $3 2 \mathrm { L }$ volume of distribution. Corrected for units, this shows 128,000 mcg currently in her system, closest to the $1 3 0 \mathrm { m g }$ given in answer choice 4.

question: A 31-year-old woman presents after ingesting a large number of aspirin tablets 2 hours ago. She denies tinnitus or GI distress. Her history is significant for major depression. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following findings is most likely present?
explanation: Salicylate toxicity is a medical emergency. A salicylate level should be checked on all patients with a concern for salicylate toxicity. Serial levels are recommended as absorption is widely variable and will impact the treatment. Acetaminophen levels should also be checked as confusion about what substance was ingested may occur. Electrolytes, including calcium and magnesium, ABG, LFTs, CBC, lactate, and coagulation studies, should be obtained. Salicylate is a hydrocarbon and is neurotoxic in overdose or chronic use. Direct stimulation of the cerebral medulla (respiratory center) causes hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis. Respiratory alkalosis is the most likely acid-base derangement based on the patient's lack of symptoms and therefore less likely mixed metabolic picture at this time. Regardless, a mixed metabolic picture is not one of the answer choices making respiratory alkalosis the most likely. Respiratory acidosis can occur with end-stage toxicity where respirations are severely depressed and ventilation is failing. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis would not be expected, salicylates cause increased lactate production accounting for the majority of free acid. Anion-gap metabolic acidosis can occur, often as a mixed picture with either an early respiratory alkalosis (Secondary to stimulation of the medulla respiratory center) or anion-gap metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis. Only respiratory alkalosis is the most likely non-mixed/compensated metabolic derangement based on the history (asymptomatic), and exam (relatively benign at this time, 2 hrs after ingestion). The metabolic picture after salicylate overdose can be complicated and often mixed metabolic presentations are not uncommon. After toxic ingestion, salicylate will stimulate the medulla respiratory center (hydrocarbon toxin) resulting in increased tachypnea and eventual early respiratory alkalosis. As toxicity pursues and often with symptoms at this time, an anion gap metabolic acidosis begins to form. Specifically, as aspirin is metabolized, it causes an uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation in the mitochondria. Lactate levels then increase due to the increase in anaerobic metabolism. The lactic acid, along with a slight contribution from the salicylate metabolites results in metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap ("MUDPILES"). As lactate levels begin to rise resulting in metabolic acidosis, a compensatory respiratory alkalosis begins (in addition to the existing early respiratory alkalosis initially present secondary to medulla stimulation in the CNS). Finally, a mixed metabolic picture involves severe respiratory acidosis (end stage of toxicity) when the patent begins to experience respiratory failure. In sum, the following can occur after an acute overdose of salicylates: (1) Early metabolic alkalosis, $\ -- > ( 2 )$ Anion Gap (lactate) metabolic acidosis (also w/ some contribution of salicylate and metabolites directly), $\ -- > ( 3 )$ Compensatory respiratory alkalosis (in response to metabolic acidosis), $\ -- > ( 4 )$ Respiratory acidosis (end-stage toxicity). Fluid resuscitation and serum alkalization will increase salicylate elimination.

question: A 34-year-old woman with a past medical history of bipolar disorder is brought to the emergency department after ingesting a large number of unknown tablets. She presents with tinnitus, vomiting, and generalized abdominal pain. Her vitals are blood pressure $1 0 0 / 7 0 \mathrm { m m H g }$ , heart rate 85 bpm, temperature 99 F (37.2 C), and respiratory rate 26 breaths/min. On examination, she appears sleepy and confused, cannot appropriately follow commands, and her speech is slurred. Lab results show elevated salicylate and alcohol levels, and the urine drug screen is positive for benzodiazepines. The bicarbonate level is $1 0 \mathrm { m g / d L }$ , an elevated anion gap of 24, and the venous blood gas shows a pH of 7.3. Which of the following is an indication for hemodialysis in this patient?
options: d. Salicylate level more than 100 mg/dL
answer: d. Salicylate level more than 100 mg/dL
explanation: Salicylate toxicity is a medical emergency that needs immediate attention and treatment. Indications for hemodialysis include altered mental status, severe acidosis $\mathrm { ( p H } 7 . 2 \mathrm { ) }$ , hypotension despite fluid resuscitation, salicylate level greater than $1 0 0 \mathrm { m g / d L }$ , mechanical ventilation, or end-organ damage. The patient in the question stem is slightly altered but also influenced by alcohol and benzodiazepines, likely contributing to her confusion. Common signs of end-organ damage in salicylate toxicity include seizures, rhabdomyolysis, pulmonary edema, cerebral edema, and renal failure. Hemodialysis removes salicylates and lactate, which should improve the patient's metabolic acidosis. In an acute salicylate overdose, the onset of symptoms will occur within 3 to 8 hours. The severity of symptoms is dependent on the amount ingested. For mild ingestions (salicylate levels 40 to $\mathrm { 8 0 ~ m g / d l } )$ ), nausea, vomiting, and generalized abdominal pain are common. Tachypnea is usually present. Headaches and dizziness may also occur. The classic finding of tinnitus may also be present. Patients with moderate salicylate toxicity (80 to $1 0 0 \mathrm { m g / d l } )$ will experience more severe neurological symptoms. These can include confusion, slurred speech, and hallucinations. Tachypnea is more pronounced and is accompanied by tachycardia and orthostatic hypotension. Expect these symptoms 6 to 18 hours after ingestion. Salicylate levels more than $1 0 0 \mathrm { m g / d L }$ are considered severe toxicity and occur 12 to 24 hours after ingestion. Damage to the basement membranes will cause cerebral and pulmonary edema. Patients may become obtunded and develop seizures. Hypoventilation may replace hyperventilation, which is concerning for impending respiratory failure. While not ideal for metabolic disorders, endotracheal intubation may be necessary for airway protection. Hypotension due to acidosis and hypovolemia is possible. Cardiac dysrhythmias may occur (sinus tachycardia is the most common). Cardiac arrest may also occur, with asystole being the most common rhythm.

question: A 16-year-old boy presents with acute onset of nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea after eating tuna. Several of his friends have similar symptoms. Vital sings are blood pressure $1 0 2 / 6 0 \mathrm { m m H g }$ , heart rate 90 bpm, respiratory rate 13 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation $9 7 \%$ on room air. On physical examination, he has a diffuse erythematous rash, no angioedema, clear lung sounds, normal heart sounds, and no abdominal tenderness to palpation. What is the most appropriate treatment plan?
options: a. Oral diphenhydramine, prednisone, and TMP-SMX.
b. IV ondansetron, diphenhydramine, and amoxicillin/clavulanic acid.
c. IV ondansetron, diphenhydramine, methylprednisolone, and cephalexin.
explanation: Histamine toxicity or scombroid poisoning is the principal chemical agent fish food-borne disease found in the United States. Symptomatic treatment is to address the overabundance of histamine. IV is preferred, given the level of vomiting in this patient. Oral antihistamines can be used with patients that can tolerate it. Unlike most food poisoning, scombroid poisoning is not brought about by ingesting a virus or bacterium. It is a reaction to an overabundance of histamine produced by bacteria. Histidine exists in many types of fish, and with air contact at temperatures ${ > } 4 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ $( 4 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )$ , it is converted to histamine via the enzyme histidine decarboxylase by many bacteria. Therefore, primary treatment is the use of antihistamines. Histidine decarboxylase (HDC), is found in Escherichia coli , Morganella morganii , and Proteus and Klebsiella species. Treatment is supportive with antihistamines, H1, and H2 blockers. This patient has no angioedema, respiratory issues, or hypotension, so sole treatment with antihistamines is appropriate. Steroids, beta-2- adrenergic agonists, ipratropium bromide, and epinephrine may be given for severe cases and anaphylaxis. An allergic-mediated reaction is on the differential, but since multiple people are experiencing similar symptoms, makes an allergic reaction significantly less likely. Therefore, steroids will not be helpful. Antibiotics are not indicated, scromboid poisoning is not an infectious process but rather an immunological response.

question: A 35-year-old man presents with a headache, dizziness, and nausea. On review of systems, the patient denies any respiratory symptoms or abdominal pain. The patient reports a recent exposure to methanethiol gas in the workplace. He has no significant history. His family history is unremarkable. Social history reveals occasional alcohol consumption and no smoking or illicit drug use. Vital signs are blood pressure $1 2 0 / 8 0 \mathrm { m m H g }$ , heart rate 80 bpm, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and temperature $3 6 . 8 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ $( 9 8 . 2 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )$ . Physical examination findings are unremarkable. Laboratory tests reveal Hb $1 4 . 5 \ : \mathrm { g / d L }$ , Hct $42 \%$ , RBC 4.5 million $ { ' }  { \mu \mathrm { L } }$ , MCV 90 fL, MCH 30 pg, MCHC $3 3 \%$ , WBC $6 { , } 0 0 0 / \mu \mathrm { L }$ , neutrophils $50 \%$ , lymphocytes $40 \%$ , monocytes $5 \%$ , eosinophils $4 \%$ , basophils $1 \%$ , and platelet count $2 5 0 { , } 0 0 0 / \mu \mathrm { L }$ . The basic metabolic panel shows sodium $1 4 0 ~ \mathrm { m E q / L }$ , potassium $4 . 0 \ : \mathrm { m E q / L }$ , chloride $1 0 0 \mathrm { m E q / L }$ , bicarbonate $2 4 \mathrm { m m o l / L }$ , BUN $1 0 \mathrm { m g / d L }$ , creatinine $0 . 9 \mathrm { m g / d L }$ , glucose 90 $\mathrm { m g / d L }$ , and calcium $9 . 0 \mathrm { m g / d L }$ . What is the most important aspect of patient education in this case?
options: a. Awareness of emergency procedures and evacuation plans in case of exposure.
b. Importance of reporting symptoms promptly to the occupational health clinic.
c. Proper use of personal protective equipment (PPE) during work activities.
d. Recognition and avoidance of further exposure to toxic gas.
answer: d. Recognition and avoidance of further exposure to toxic gas.
explanation: In this scenario, the patient presents with symptoms of headache, dizziness, and nausea following exposure to mercaptan gas (methanethiol). The most important aspect of patient education, in this case, is the recognition and avoidance of further exposure to mercaptan gas. Educating the patient about the signs and symptoms of mercaptan toxicity will help them identify and prevent future exposures. Awareness of emergency procedures and evacuation plans is valuable but not the primary concern for patient education in this case. Prompt reporting of symptoms to the occupational health clinic is important but not the primary focus of education in this scenario. Proper use of personal protective equipment (PPE) is crucial for preventing exposure but may not be the most important aspect for this patient at this stage.

question: A 31-year-old man presents with progressive confusion and drowsiness 3 days after an uncomplicated hernia repair under halothane anesthesia. His symptoms started with fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. He has no significant history and takes acetaminophen for occasional headaches. He has had several same-sex relationships and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are temperature $3 7 . 9 ^ { \circ }$ C $( 1 0 0 . 2 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )$ , blood pressure 108/66 mm Hg, and heart rate 112 bpm. On physical examination, the patient is somnolent, wakes to painful stimuli, and is disoriented but follows simple instructions, He is jaundiced and has tender hepatomegaly, and asterixis. There are no stigmata of chronic liver disease. You suspected acute liver failure due to halothane toxicity. Which of the following laboratory studies is most indicative of acute (fulminant) liver failure?
explanation: Decreased serum albumin is commonly present in chronic liver disease and may be present in later stages of acute liver failure. It is not a classic finding in halothane toxicity associated with liver failure. The diagnosis of acute liver failure requires severe liver injury as evidenced by elevated aminotransferases, signs of hepatic encephalopathy, and synthetic liver dysfunction. Defined as a prolonged prothrombin time with $\mathrm { I N R } > 1 . 5$ . Acute renal insufficiency, evidenced by elevated serum creatinine, is common in ALF (up to $70 \%$ of cases) and is likely due to decreased renal perfusion / direct renal tubular toxicity in some cases. However, it is not specific for acute liver failure. A hallmark clinical presentation of halothane toxicity-associated liver failure is a mixture of a high fever, tender hepatomegaly, and jaundice starting 2-3 days post halothane exposure followed rapidly by signs of acute liver failure.

question: A 42-year-old man with a history of substance use disorder is admitted after being found unresponsive in the street. In the emergency department, he is noted to be hypoglycemic with a blood glucose of $\mathrm { 3 0 m g / d l }$ and is started on an intravenous dextrose infusion at 100 ml/hour. On physical exam, he remains unresponsive, reflexes are intact, and the cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Blood work shows an elevated glyburide level, and a diagnosis of glyburide overdose is made. One hour after starting the dextrose infusion, he remains unresponsive. A repeat blood glucose level is $4 5 \mathrm { m g / d l }$ . What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
options: d. Increase the rate of the dextrose infusion
explanation: Octreotide is a somatostatin analog that inhibits insulin release from pancreatic beta-islet cells and should be used along with dextrose in the treatment of sulfonylurea overdose. Octreotide can be given as an intravenous, intramuscular (IM), or subcutaneous (SC) injection. The recommended dose is 50 to 150 mcg given IM or SC every six hours. Dextrose should not be used as monotherapy in managing sulfonylurea overdose as it can cause a transient increase in blood insulin levels and a worsening of hypoglycemia.

question: A 35-year-old man presents with a one-year history of thickening and painful fissuring of skin over soles and decreased appetite. Over the last five months, he has been experiencing tingling and numbness in the distal part of the extremities. The patient mentions he worked in a mine for 12 years. On examination, there are hypopigmented macules on hyperpigmented skin, which are localized on his trunk. There is diffuse thickening of the skin over the soles and palms, more severe on soles, which also exhibit fissures. A spot urine sample confirms the suspected diagnosis. Which of the following is commonly used to describe the pigmentation pattern seen in this patient's condition?
options: c. Raindrop on a dusty road
answer: c. Raindrop on a dusty road
explanation: Hyperpigmentation of skin is the earliest cutaneous manifestation of chronic arsenic toxicity. Along with arsenical keratosis, it is the most common presenting complaint of arsenicosis. Cutaneous hyperpigmentation can be generalized, diffuse or localized, patchy hyperpigmentation which is prominent over the skin folds. Patients can have multiple hyperpigmented macules symmetrically distributed over the trunk and extremities, described as raindrop pattern, or guttate hypopigmented macules on a background of hyperpigmentation described as a raindrop on a dusty road. Hyperpigmented macules or patches are not usually biopsied as they do not exhibit any potential to become malignant. Histopathological examination of the skin lesion shows increased melanin throughout the epidermis with no proliferation of melanocytes or atypical keratinocytes.
